claim: If a task takes 2 days and starts on Friday, it ends on Sunday

supporting.text: Friday is day 1, Saturday is day 2, so the task ends on Sunday.

attacks.text: Friday is day 1, Saturday is day 2, so the task ends on Sunday.
If the task starts at the end of Friday (e.g., 11 PM), day 2 may extend into Monday.
Most tasks are assumed to start at the beginning of the day unless specified otherwise.
Time zones or international work schedules could shift the end day to Monday.
Standard business conventions typically assume local time unless stated otherwise.

supporting.text: Starting on Friday and counting two full days lands the completion on Sunday.

attacks.text: Starting on Friday and counting two full days lands the completion on Sunday.
Counting two full days from Friday includes Saturday and Sunday, but the task ends at the end of Sunday, not necessarily on Sunday.
If the task starts at the beginning of Friday, two full days would end at the beginning of Sunday, not the end.

supporting.text: A 2-day duration from Friday includes Friday and Saturday, ending on Sunday.

attacks.text: A 2-day duration from Friday includes Friday and Saturday, ending on Sunday.
If 'starts on Friday' means the task begins at midnight Friday, and '2 days' means 48 hours, it would end at midnight Sunday, not necessarily 'on Sunday' in common usage.
In most scheduling contexts, 'days' refer to calendar days, not strict 24-hour periods, so Friday to Sunday is the correct interpretation.

supporting.text: If Friday is the start date, the next day is Saturday, and the day after is Sunday, marking the end of the task.

attacks.text: If Friday is the start date, the next day is Saturday, and the day after is Sunday, marking the end of the task.
